claim.text: Seeds must be stored cool and dry — 4°C and below 40% relative humidity for long-term viability
claim.claim: Optimal seed storage conditions are 4°C and below 40% relative humidity

results.summary: The stated conditions of 4°C and below 40% relative humidity align with widely accepted seed storage standards.
results.detail: These conditions match guidelines from major seed banks and agricultural research institutions. The Svalbard Global Seed Vault stores seeds at -18°C, while the FAO/IPGRI Genebank Standards recommend -18°C to -20°C for base collections and 1-4°C for active collections, with relative humidity of 3-7% for dried seeds or seed moisture content of 3-7%. The claim of 4°C and 40% RH represents a reasonable standard for medium-term storage rather than the most stringent long-term conditions, but is within accepted practice.
sources: General agricultural extension literature on seed storage (training knowledge)

claim.text: Most vegetable seeds remain viable for 3-7 years under proper storage
claim.claim: Most vegetable seeds remain viable for 3-7 years under proper storage conditions

results.summary: The 3-7 year viability range for most vegetable seeds under proper storage is consistent with widely published agricultural extension guidelines.
results.detail: University agricultural extension services (such as those from Oregon State, University of Minnesota, and Cornell) consistently report that most vegetable seeds remain viable for 2-5 years on the shorter end and up to 5-7+ years for longer-lasting varieties like tomatoes and brassicas when stored cool and dry. The claim's 3-7 year range reasonably captures this variation. However, I was unable to perform live web searches to verify current sources.
sources: Unable to access web sources - verdict based on training knowledge of agricultural extension publications
